snippet.title: üî•üî• 101 SPECIAL | POLITICIAN MATHRAME KAADUU | Ft. Raghunandan Rao | Telugu Podcast|Raw Talks With VK
snippet.description:
Madhavaneni Raghunandan Rao ‚Äì MP Lok Sabha, Medak constituency, Ex-MLA (Dubbak) , and a Lawyer by profession.

In this Telugu podcast episode, we sit down with Raghunandan Rao, to uncover the harsh realities of Indian politics. Known for his bold voice, Rao speaks candidly about one of the most debated issues today; over 250 parliamentarians facing criminal cases. He reflects on the charges against him, the toll they take on families, and why the system itself needs a serious rethink. From the controversial ‚ÄúBJP washing machine‚Äù narrative to the gap between perception and reality, nothing is left unsaid.

Rao also shares the resilience that kept him going despite multiple defeats, comparing politics to Darwin‚Äôs theory of survival, using the giraffe & dinosaur example. He questions the double standards around freedom of speech, why anonymous trolls are tolerated while political voices face silencing, and how social media has reshaped the language of politics in India.

Beyond speeches and headlines, he reveals the everyday life of a politician; endless public interactions, health issues like BP and diabetes, heavy spending on hospitality, and the emotional cost on families. He also weighs in on Telangana‚Äôs contribution to central taxes, the rise in petrol prices, and whether national parties like BJP can break through in states rooted in regional identities.

From courtroom battles to political wars, from personal regrets to advice for the youth, this episode brings out the unfiltered side of a leader who has built his career on persistence and outspoken conviction. If you're someone curious about the complex mix of power, politics, and survival in India, this is an episode you can‚Äôt afford to miss.

.
Disclaimer: This video is for educational purposes only. The opinions expressed by the guests are their personal views and do not reflect our stance. We have no intention of defaming or harming any individual, brand, product, country, or profession mentioned in this video. Our aim is to provide information to help the audience make informed decisions.
~

In today‚Äôs episode of Figuring Out, we have one of the most loved standup comedians Zakir Khan in conversation with Raj Shamani. This episode will take you in the world of stories and beautiful realisations. While Zakir is sharing some heartwarming stories from his life but those are so relatable that they will feel like your own stories. We talked about how confidence changes in different situations, how success feels to him. He shared his experience being the first Indian comedian to perform at Royal Albert Hall London.

We also had a deep conversation on the art of storytelling, what it takes to be a good storyteller, how storytelling is important in different fields and how lack of it affects relationships. He also shared how one can improve their storytelling skills. We talked about why there is an increasing loneliness felt by today‚Äôs generation and how they can overcome it. He also shared some heart moving stories of his father. He described his relationship with his mother and how it has evolved over the years. He also shared some qualities every father should have. 

We ended the podcast by talking about the importance of relationships for our mental health and wellbeing and how we can find a balance in each of those relationships. We talked about love and how we can nurture a relationship for years. At the end, Zakir shared what it takes to become a winner in life. This podcast for me, was like watching a movie. I was crying, laughing and my heart felt warmed.

Do subscribe to our channel and join us on this journey of Figuring Out and don‚Äôt forget to press the bell button to get notified everytime we post a new podcast.

In today‚Äôs episode, we have Bharti Singh, one of India‚Äôs most loved comedians and entertainers, known for her iconic characters, infectious laughter, and incredible journey from small-town struggles to becoming a household name. From her early days on Laughter Challenge to building a career that changed comedy on television, Bharti opens up about her life, her work, and what really shaped her success.

We talk about the hardships she faced growing up, losing her father at a young age, her mother‚Äôs struggles, and how those experiences gave her the grit to chase her dreams. Bharti shares stories of pushing through trolling, surviving rejection, dealing with fears, and balancing her family with her love for work. She also reflects on her relationship with Harsh, her bond with Kapil Sharma, and the role of YouTube in reinventing her career.

In the last segment, she speaks about what success really means to her, the insecurities she still battles, and why she wants her son to grow up with different opportunities than she had. Bharti shares her journey in a raw, funny, and deeply inspiring way. 

Subscribe for more such conversations!

Finally, he shares how he hopes to be remembered by the world.

In today‚Äôs episode, we have Karan Aujla, singer, lyricist, and one of the most influential voices in Punjabi music. He opens up about the struggles behind fame, from losing his parents at a young age to facing extortion threats and violence in Canada. Despite success, he reflects on the void he still feels and the fears that continue to shape his life and music.

We dive into his emotional side, how he views love, marriage, and family, why he writes songs from a female perspective, and the stories behind some of his most popular tracks. Karan also talks about his insecurities, the pressure of constantly creating, and the balance between vulnerability and strength as a public figure. He also reveals his habit of reckless spending, the making of his new album, and the artists he draws inspiration from.

In the last segment, he shares how loneliness follows him despite success, how his wife anchors him, and why he still feels a constant need to protect his loved ones. He also opens up about what truly defines happiness for him today. This episode was delivered by Porter.

In today‚Äôs episode, we have Karan Aujla, singer, lyricist, and one of the most influential voices in Punjabi music. He opens up about the struggles behind fame, from losing his parents at a young age to facing extortion threats and violence in Canada. Despite success, he reflects on the void he still feels and the fears that continue to shape his life and music.

We dive into his emotional side, how he views love, marriage, and family, why he writes songs from a female perspective, and the stories behind some of his most popular tracks. Karan also talks about his insecurities, the pressure of constantly creating, and the balance between vulnerability and strength as a public figure. He also reveals his habit of reckless spending, the making of his new album, and the artists he draws inspiration from.

In the last segment, he shares how loneliness follows him despite success, how his wife anchors him, and why he still feels a constant need to protect his loved ones. He also opens up about what truly defines happiness for him today. This episode was delivered by Porter.

---------------

In this episode, Karan Johar opens up about his journey, not just as a filmmaker and producer, but as someone constantly adapting to an ever-changing industry. He addresses the recent flops of his films, and also reflects on what the word ‚Äúsuccess‚Äù really means in an industry where public opinion changes overnight.

Karan opens up about his personal battles from the trauma of losing his father to how bullying and societal expectations shaped his early years. He talks about the pressure to appear a certain way and finding comfort in loneliness despite being seen as a social figure. There‚Äôs also discussion about mental health, public perception, and how fame comes with its own disadvantages. He even clears the air around speculation regarding his weight loss.

In the last segment, he speaks about the realities of launching star kids. From his creative process to his deepest insecurities and the stories behind iconic films like Kuch Kuch Hota Hai and Ae Dil Hai Mushkil, this episode reveals the other side of the story of a man who has always been much more than just the controversies surrounding him.

In this episode, we talk to Vijay Mallya once known as the King of Good Times. He opens up about the rise of Kingfisher, the fall that followed, and the personal cost of building an empire that couldn‚Äôt survive.

We explore how his larger-than-life image was built, how flamboyance became a business strategy, and why his father‚Äôs legacy shaped every move he made. From airlines and IPL to Formula 1 and luxury lifestyles, Mallya reflects on the choices that defined him.

He shares why he believes business failure is seen as fraud in India, why he regrets starting Kingfisher Airlines, and how the media shaped public opinion against him. He also talks about repaying more than he borrowed, the pain of letting go, and the long silence he‚Äôs finally breaking.

In the final segment, he addresses the question everyone‚Äôs been asking  will he return to India? And in the end, was he a showman, a businessman, or simply misunderstood?

He shares why he believes business failure is seen as fraud in India, why he regrets starting Kingfisher Airlines, and how the media shaped public opinion against him. He also talks about repaying more than he borrowed, the pain of letting go, and the long silence he‚Äôs finally breaking.

In the final segment, he addresses the question everyone‚Äôs been asking  will he return to India? And in the end, was he a showman, a businessman, or simply misunderstood?

Subscribe for more conversations with extraordinary guests.

In today‚Äôs episode of Figuring Out, we have India‚Äôs music sensation, Diljit Dosanjh in conversation with Raj Shamani. He is one of the most loved Indian singers in India and globally. This is one of the most special podcasts we had on our channel.

In this episode, we talked about why he mentions Punjab and not India when he performs, how he represented India at Coachella, and the story behind Shah Rukh Khan telling Imtiaz Ali that Diljit Dosanjh is the best actor in India. We further talked about why SRK became a big brand and is loved by everyone, his experience meeting him, the story of him running away from home when he was 7 years old, and why he chose Karan Aujla to write the song G.O.A.T. He also shared stories from his childhood and how his perspective and life changed in 2020. 

We further talked about why many artists don‚Äôt become successful after 5-7 years in their career and what is he doing right to stay relevant for so many years. We discussed why he works with new artists most of the time and how his music production changed after G.O.A.T. Towards the end, we talked about his love life, his first love, and his diet. He shared his experience performing at Ambani‚Äôs wedding and his current music tour. For more such interesting episodes, don‚Äôt forget to subscribe to our channel!

snippet.title: The Future Mark Zuckerberg Is Trying To Build
snippet.description:
The Huge Conversation with Mark Zuckerberg...

I interviewed Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg before Connect. There are not many people with more power over our future. Right now, Mark Zuckerberg and his team are imagining the future billions of people might live in, soon, and building towards it. So, in this conversation, my goal is to figure out what that future looks like. To paint a picture of the future Mark Zuckerberg is trying to build, so that you can decide for yourself what you think of it.

We talked about the Meta's new Orion prototype AR glasses, creating holograms and the Star Trek universal translator, generative AI changing social media, big trends in human connection, open sourced AI, Ray Ban Meta glasses and Quest 3S, the biggest genuine question on his mind right now, and more... 

Welcome to the first episode of our new series, Huge Conversations‚Ä¶

Special thanks to Derek Thompson, for his generous guidance on my first long-form interview!

Chapters: 
0:00 What is Mark Zuckerberg trying to build?
2:08 Meta's new Orion prototype AR glasses
4:42 How do Meta's Orion glasses work?
6:55 What's the future of AR?
9:50 What's the future of VR?
11:36 What is Meta trying to build?
13:18 Haptics is hard
17:18 Why does VR feel real?
20:16 Why are we having trouble connecting?
24:27 What should we use AI for?
28:17 What wouldn't he want his kids using AI for?
31:47 How will generative AI change social media?
35:43 What concerns does he see as most legitimate?
39:26 Why care about open source?
43:38 What is his biggest genuine question?

You can find me on Instagram here: https://www.instagram.com/cleoabram 
On TikTok here: https://www.tiktok.com/@cleoabram 
Or on Twitter here: https://twitter.com/cleoabram 

Bio:
Cleo Abram is a video journalist who produces Huge If True, an optimistic show about science and technology. Huge If True is an antidote to the doom and gloom, helping a wide audience see better futures they can help build. In each episode, Cleo dives deep into one innovation that could shape the future. She has explored humanoid robots at Boston Dynamics, supersonic planes at NASA, quantum computers at IBM, the Large Hadron Collider at CERN, and more. Every episode mixes high quality animations and detailed scripts with relatable vlog-style journeys, taking the audience along for an adventure to answer the question: If this works, what could go right? Previously, Cleo was a video producer at Vox and directed for Explained on Netflix. She was the host of Vox‚Äôs first ever daily show, Answered, as well as co-host of Vox‚Äôs YouTube Originals show, Glad You Asked.

Vox: https://www.vox.com/authors/cleo-abram
IMDb: https://www.imdb.com/name/nm10108242/ 

Gear I use: 
Camera: Sony A7SIII
Lens: Sony 16‚Äì35 mm F2.8 GM
Audio: Sennheiser SK AVX and Zoom H4N Pro

Music: Musicbed, Tom Fox

‚Äî

Less than three

localized.description:
The Huge Conversation with Mark Zuckerberg...

I interviewed Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg before Connect. There are not many people with more power over our future. Right now, Mark Zuckerberg and his team are imagining the future billions of people might live in, soon, and building towards it. So, in this conversation, my goal is to figure out what that future looks like. To paint a picture of the future Mark Zuckerberg is trying to build, so that you can decide for yourself what you think of it.

We talked about the Meta's new Orion prototype AR glasses, creating holograms and the Star Trek universal translator, generative AI changing social media, big trends in human connection, open sourced AI, Ray Ban Meta glasses and Quest 3S, the biggest genuine question on his mind right now, and more... 

Welcome to the first episode of our new series, Huge Conversations‚Ä¶

Special thanks to Derek Thompson, for his generous guidance on my first long-form interview!

Chapters: 
0:00 What is Mark Zuckerberg trying to build?
2:08 Meta's new Orion prototype AR glasses
4:42 How do Meta's Orion glasses work?
6:55 What's the future of AR?
9:50 What's the future of VR?
11:36 What is Meta trying to build?
13:18 Haptics is hard
17:18 Why does VR feel real?
20:16 Why are we having trouble connecting?
24:27 What should we use AI for?
28:17 What wouldn't he want his kids using AI for?
31:47 How will generative AI change social media?
35:43 What concerns does he see as most legitimate?
39:26 Why care about open source?
43:38 What is his biggest genuine question?

You can find me on Instagram here: https://www.instagram.com/cleoabram 
On TikTok here: https://www.tiktok.com/@cleoabram 
Or on Twitter here: https://twitter.com/cleoabram 

Bio:
Cleo Abram is a video journalist who produces Huge If True, an optimistic show about science and technology. Huge If True is an antidote to the doom and gloom, helping a wide audience see better futures they can help build. In each episode, Cleo dives deep into one innovation that could shape the future. She has explored humanoid robots at Boston Dynamics, supersonic planes at NASA, quantum computers at IBM, the Large Hadron Collider at CERN, and more. Every episode mixes high quality animations and detailed scripts with relatable vlog-style journeys, taking the audience along for an adventure to answer the question: If this works, what could go right? Previously, Cleo was a video producer at Vox and directed for Explained on Netflix. She was the host of Vox‚Äôs first ever daily show, Answered, as well as co-host of Vox‚Äôs YouTube Originals show, Glad You Asked.

Vox: https://www.vox.com/authors/cleo-abram

Shahid opens up about his childhood, his parents' separation, and how those experiences influenced his personality and relationships.

He reflects on the evolution of his career, from overcoming underconfidence to making choices that pushed him beyond his comfort zone. Shahid also talks about parenting, his bond with his kids, and the lessons he hopes to pass on to them. He delves into his idea of a ‚Äúhealthy marriage,‚Äù emphasising respect, understanding, and individuality in relationships.

From memories of working with Bollywood legends to his thoughts on family, success, and failure, this conversation is a treasure trove of life lessons and candid moments. So, in this episode, you'll see the most real side of Shahid Kapoor that you've ever seen. And the way he opened up, it just felt like two bros chilling together, sharing stories and laughs so make sure you don‚Äôt miss this episode.

THE SHOW:
Hasan Minhaj Doesn‚Äôt Know is a long-form interview podcast hosted by two-time Peabody Award-winning comedian Hasan Minhaj. The show features in-depth conversations with politicians and public figures, as well as occasional interviews with celebrities. Rather than sticking to standard talking points, Minhaj aims to ask deeper, more probing questions that reveal personal perspectives and challenge conventional narratives. The tone is direct and curious, and focused on uncovering what guests really think beyond rehearsed answers.

In today‚Äôs episode, Vivek Agarwal, a crime journalist and author who has spent decades uncovering the darkest corners of India‚Äôs underworld, shares stories from meeting gangsters face-to-face to navigating threats that come with exposing the truth.

We explore the difference between mafia and t*rrorists, the rise and fall of Haji Mastaan, and how Dawood Ibrahim built an empire driven by fear, ambition, and money. Vivek also dives deep into dance bars as underworld hotspots, the glamorization through movies, and how real crime is far from what films show.

In the last segment he discusses gambling apps, judicial reforms, and the impact of corruption on law enforcement.

About This Podcast - 

In this Telugu podcast, we sit down with the one and only Ram Gopal Varma (RGV) ‚Äî the man who redefined Indian cinema with films like Shiva, Satya, Company, and Rakta Charitra. Known for his fearless opinions and unconventional filmmaking style, RGV opens up like never before in this no-holds-barred conversation.
We dive into how creative freedom is shrinking in the current film industry, why critics are just paid opinion-makers, and how social media has changed the power dynamic between creators and the audience. RGV talks about the elements in his movies that he thought would become hits ‚Äî but surprisingly went unnoticed ‚Äî and shares honest thoughts on why certain films flop despite having all the right ingredients.
Whether you‚Äôre a filmmaker, student, or just a fan of cinema ‚Äî this episode is a rollercoaster of ideas, rebellion, and pure honesty.
This episode goes beyond cinema ‚Äî it‚Äôs about psychology, creativity, resistance, and staying true to yourself in a world that demands conformity.
A raw, powerful, and unfiltered conversation ‚Äî this is Ram Gopal Varma like you‚Äôve never seen him before.
 Don‚Äôt miss it!

snippet.title: The Art of Not Giving a F with Taraji P. Henson
snippet.description:
Taraji P. Henson keeps it ALL the way real! The Oscar-nominated queen dishes on motherhood in her 20s, the art of not caring in her 50s, and what it takes to protect your peace while still thriving in Hollywood. Plus, we get into love, dating, and why no man is entitled to live in her house (seriously, he doesn‚Äôt even get a drawer!). From ‚ÄòBaby Boy‚Äô to ‚ÄòHidden Figures‚Äô to the unforgettable Cookie Lyon, Taraji reflects on her legendary career and reveals why now is finally the right time for her Broadway debut. 

CONTENT WARNING: This conversation includes mentions of suicide. If you or someone you know is struggling, please reach out to the 988 Suicide & Crisis Lifeline (U.S.) or your local support line.

10:35 Why her Broadway debut is full circle
